newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West Coast lt. crudes up with WTI, no deals.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West Coast lt. crudes up with WTI, no deals.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crudes climbed with a slighter higher WTI/Cushing market on Friday, while differentials stayed flat amid thin discussion, traders said.

A small parcel of Line 63 crude sold Thursday for $1.00 over California Buena Vista crude. The deal, confirmed by both buyer and seller, amounted to 1,000 bpd for March delivery to a mid-sized Los Angeles refiner.
Smaller refiners also sought similar-sized deals of Line 63, a lookalike for Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude, at the same price.

Traders said Line 63 prices stood at postings plus $0.95 - $1.05, with the WTI-based market assessed at minus $1.95 to minus $1.85 under WTI. Buyers and sellers said supplies remain adequate for March.
ANS prices moved up with March spot WTI, which rose five cents from Thursday to $21.95/22.05 a barrel.
BP, the main seller of ANS, continued to decline an offering price, with buyers claiming they have ship scheduling problems.
BP denied it had scheduling problems, and has said it remains out of the market to assess its supplies.
Meanwhile, buyers said March business was nearly over for ANS. They remained out of the market to determined what month to peg bids off of.
Some buyers continued to shop for foreign curdes, traders said, but deliveries were unlikely to reach refineries until early April.
Kern River heavy crude remained $14 53/14.73 a barrel, trader said.

Traders said Texaco plans to bring in a 300,000 barrel ship of Eocene crude, a grade similar to California's Outer Continental Shelf (OSC) grade which is shipped down Line 63 from mid-California to refineries in the southern half of the state.
Traders said the import could displace some of Texaco's OCS business.
